title: Stable Matchings with Restricted Preferences: Structure and Complexity

sections.introduction: In the last 60 years, the stable marriage problem and its variants have emerged as central topics in economics, computer science, and mathematics. The basic problem is phrased as follows. Let Mğ‘€M and Wğ‘ŠW be two disjoint sets of nğ‘›n agents, traditionally referred to as men and women, respectively. Each agent has a preference list that ranks (all or some) members of the opposite sex. The goal is to find a matching Î¼ğœ‡\mu between Mğ‘€M and Wğ‘ŠW such that no mâˆˆMğ‘šğ‘€m\in M and wâˆˆWğ‘¤ğ‘Šw\in W mutually prefer each other to their partners in Î¼ğœ‡\mu. Such a matching is called stable. In their seminal work, Gale and ShapleyÂ  proved that a stable matching Î¼ğœ‡\mu always exists and provided an Oâ€‹(n2)ğ‘‚superscriptğ‘›2O(n^{2}) time algorithm for finding one. This run-time has been shown to be optimal in a variety of computational modelsÂ 8 . While a stable matching instance of size nğ‘›n may have 2Î˜â€‹(n)superscript2Î˜ğ‘›2^{\Theta(n)} stable matchingsÂ 1 , the Gale-Shapley algorithm outputs only two kinds of stable matchingsâ€”the man-optimal/woman-pessimal and the woman-optimal/man-pessimal stable matchings. That is, these stable matchings are the best for one group of agents but the worst for the other group. To address this inequity, researchers investigated various notions of â€œfairâ€ stable matchingsÂ 1       [ref]7     and studied the problem of counting and sampling stable matchings uniformly at randomÂ    . For all of these problems, crucial insights are gained by understanding the combinatorial structure of the set of stable matchings. They include computing a median stable matchingÂ   [ref]7, a balanced stable matchingÂ  or a sex-equal stable matchingÂ  . A natural approach then is to consider stable matching instances whose preference lists are restricted but nevertheless model situations that arise in practice. Below, we consider three such models from the work of Bhatnagar et al.Â . In the kğ‘˜k-attribute model, each agent has an associated kğ‘˜k-dimensional profile and their preference lists are determined by applying a linear function to the profiles of their potential partners. The model is motivated by online dating sites. In this context, participants are frequently asked an extensive set of questions. Some answers are used to create a participantâ€™s profile while other answers are used to formulate a function that ranks possible dates according to the othersâ€™ profiles. In the kğ‘˜k-range model, there is an objective ranking for each set of agents. Each person ranks agents from the other group to within kğ‘˜k of their objective ranks. This model captures the scenario when participants make use of â€œofficial rankingsâ€ to create their preference lists. Students, for instance, might use their stateâ€™s ranking of nearby high schools to guide their choices, while the schools might base their preferences according to the studentsâ€™ test scores. The participants do not have to copy the official rankings exactly; but they cannot deviate that much from the objective ranks when they make their choices. In the kğ‘˜k-list model, each set of agents can be partitioned into kğ‘˜k groups such that agents within each group have identical preference lists. The model applies to situations when students who aspire to be engineers all have the same preferences, students who plan to pursue a business-related major have the same preferences, etc. Similarly, high schools with a STEM focus may rank students the same way while high schools with a focus on the arts may have their own rankings. That is, even under narrow conditions, MCMC is not a feasible method for sampling stable matchings. FollowingÂ , Chebolu et al.Â  considered the problem of counting the number of stable matchings (#â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM}) for instances in the kğ‘˜k-attribute model and a related kğ‘˜k-Euclidean model (introduced by Bogomolnaia and LaslierÂ ). They showed that #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} is #â€‹BIS#BIS\mathrm{\#BIS}-complete even when the preference lists are restricted to the 333-attribute and 222-Euclidean models. Thus, under a widely believed conjecture of Dyer et al.Â 2, #â€‹SM#SM\mathrm{\#SM} does not admit a fully polynomial randomized approximation scheme (FPRAS). Chebolu et al. established their result for the 333-attribute model by showing that for any bipartite graph GğºG, there is a 333-attribute stable matching instance whose rotation posetâ€™s Hasse diagram is isomorphic to GğºG.111The intent is for the independent sets of GğºG to be in one-to-one correspondence with the downsets of the rotation poset. Bhatnagar et al.Â  and Chebolu et al.Â  established their hardness results by constructing stable matching instances with restricted preference lists that realized certain families of rotation posets. Our goal is to go a step further: to characterize the family of rotation posets realized by restricted families of stable matching instances.
